data.title: Ian McEwan’s enduring ire over East Anglia writing course cuts
data.meta_description: Ian McEwan says the University of East Anglia would be “shooting themselves in the foot, if not in the head” if it makes cuts to its world-famous creative writing programme
data.text:
Ian McEwan says the University of East Anglia would be “shooting themselves in the foot, if not in the head” if it makes cuts to its world-famous creative writing programme.

The Enduring Love and Atonement author said the time he spent at the university as a young writer “changed my life” and condemned cuts to the programme as “gross bureaucratic folly”.

Last week the university, which is £30 million in debt, announced that it was cutting 113 jobs, many in administration, to try to balance its books. Among the 36 academic redundancies, 31 are in the arts and humanities faculties, including some in the creative writing department. Some staff on the creative writing course are understood already to have taken jobs elsewhere.
